jcr:content.jcr:description: What happens when Swinburne teachers can’t agree? We put them in the Course Face-off arena! This time the Bachelor of Criminal Justice and Criminology faces off against Bachelor of Laws… who wins?
jcr:content.jcr:title: Course Face-off: Crime and Punishment | Swinburne University of Technology, Melbourne

text.text:
Course Face-off: Crime and Punishment

Welcome to our Course Face-off series where two academics back their course in a winner-takes-all battle for supremacy.

text_498580732.text: Professsor Dan Hunter [left] and Professor Mirko Bagaric [right] square off.

text_745380948.text:
“Who am I fighting with?” asks Professor Dan Hunter, Dean of Swinburne Law School.

Criminal Justice and Criminology. The folks who focus on the causes and fallout of crime.

“But, what? They are part of my gang, I can’t slag them off… We are sexier than them, though.”

That’s how it started, with a bit of trash talk before the weigh-in ­– a bachelor degree knock-out event starring…

text_1734613677.text:
Bachelor of Criminal Justice and Criminology

vs

Bachelor of Laws

text_1132705379.text: In the corner for Criminal Justice and Criminology we have Professor Mirko Bagaric. And, in the Laws corner, we have the man, who is… well… Mirko’s boss, the founding dean of Swinburne Law School, Professor Dan Hunter.

text_942128529.text:
Which graduates are going to turn out the better true crime podcast?

Dan: The Criminal Justice and Criminology grads might have a few more stories up their sleeves, but the law students can control a room and read an audience. They’ll have presented in front of some of the toughest critics around in moot courts. So, for me, it’s really a question of style over content.

Spoken like a true lawyer there. Throwing a little shade with just a hint of that lawyerly brashness.

Mirko: Criminals exhibit some of the most extreme, bizarre and sometimes cruel behaviours toward other human beings. It’s hard to reconcile and comprehend these behaviours that exist on the absolute margins.

Yikes. So… the podcast?

Mirko: Oh, there’s no doubt a Criminal Justice and Criminology graduate will turn out the better podcast. Understanding and learning about what motivates criminal activity is simply fascinating, and finding ways to eradicate these behaviours, even more so.

text_2002434602.text: Dan doesn't looked convinced by Mirko's claims.

text_1385116275.text:
Who's going to save the world?

We’ll give you the first trot on this one, Mirko.

Mirko: That’s easy. Can you imagine a lawyer saving the world?

Dan: Apart from environmental, public interest and human rights lawyers…? Or simply those who defend the defenceless...?

Mirko: Yes, apart from those. Criminal Justice and Criminology actually looks at ways to prevent crime, as opposed to just dealing with it once a crime has been committed.

Dan: On the other hand, lawyers develop a whole series of skills – they debate, they write (we teach them to write better than they ever have before), they discuss policy ideas around how society, politics and business are organised. And our graduates will actually learn how to move those levers that control the world.

Thank you, Dan. Before we move on, let’s acknowledge our omnipotent overlords… every lawyer ever.

text_1955750673.text: Dan and Mirko stand back to back - unable to reach consensus.

text_1689326380.text:
Which character from pop culture are graduates most likely to become?

Dan: Look, doesn’t everyone want to be Harvey Specter or Jessica Pearson?

Mirko: No.

Dan: These guys live amazing lives. They have chauffeurs. I’m the Dean of a Law School, I don’t have a chauffeur! I want to be Harvey Specter, I want a chauffeur!

Mirko: I see students coming to study Criminal Justice and Criminology with strong social justice motivations, these are people that have a desire to make a difference to the community in a profound way.

Dan: Our law students have the same motivations, and they, like us, are focused on the future. We are the only law school in Victoria preparing students for the fundamental shifts in law being brought about by new technology and innovation.

Mirko: Look, I’m going with Sherlock Holmes. He finds solutions to complex problems, he is fantastic with details and he looks at things very methodically.

Okay, Mirko. Stretching the parameters of pop culture a bit there… but Holmes probably just sneaks in thanks to Cumberbatch.

Mirko: That’s it, I concede, I’m too old for smack talk.

Alright, Mirko’s thrown in the towel, climbed through the ropes and is heading for the door. 

That’s Bachelor of Criminal Justice and Criminology vs. Bachelor of Laws done and dusted (for fingerprints).

text_276991761.text:
Still have questions you need answering?

Contact us and we'll help you take your next steps.
